title: When filing ch. 13 does lawyer have discretion figuring out home equity or is there a set in stone formula?
question: When filing chapter 13 and calculating the monthly amount that client will pay trustee how does the lawyer calculate equity in home?
answers: My colleagues have provided good information for you. I do urge you to talk with your chapter 13 attorney - if you don't have one, I urge you to get one. Valuation of your house, and other assets, is important for your case and impacts several issues related to the case. Get specific advice about your assets before filing the case.

I agree with colleagues and add:
Each real property is unique. I generally use current FMV taking into consideration all factors that affect value of your particular property.
You are represented. Your attorney in best position to assess all factors related to your property. Review questions with your attorney.

As the owner you are qualified to propose a current value, but if any party in interest challenges the value because it makes a difference in terms of your exemptions, the Court may set an evidentiary hearing and the Court will decide the value. Therefore it may make sense for your attorney to consult with an appraiser.

You should discuss this with your lawyer. Home value is subjective, there is no formula. Usually you can file your case listing the value you believe your home is worth based on its conditions and offers you received can be taken into consideration. If the chapter 13 trustee feels the value is too low he/she may request proof of the value of the home and you will then likely need to get it appraised by a professional. The trustee will then likely go with the appraised value. I agree with my colleague above that the chapter 13 trustee will require you to pay your unsecured creditors as much as they would receive in a chapter 7 liquidation of your home.

The values you chose to use on every asset in your bankruptcy petition is subject to challenges from both the trustee and your creditors. Chose a lowball value, and the cost of defending a challenge may eat up all the money you thought you were savings and damage both you and your attorney's credibility in the future. We call this "penny wise, pound foolish." Hope this perspective helps!

Ask your lawyer is and will always be the best answer in ch. 13. Why? Because that person knows/should know everything about your property and your financial condition.

Just to add; fmv affects home value, as do liens, HOA dues, and statutory liens. However, there are certain levels of compensation for a ch. 7 trustee, so called administrative fees, that should (depending on case law in your jurisdiction) be deducted from the equity available to creditors. You may also be able to (depending on case law) be able to deduct average realtor commission and transfer tax from the equity.

Good luck! But, rely on your attorney! And if you have trust issues, address them now!! Ch. 13 is a long term relationship, it must be built on trust.

I would fully agree with what the other attorneys have told you. However, I would add to this the following:

What the present value of your house is and the debt that is owed on it can be major factors in determining what, if anything, you may have to pay unsecured creditors. I regularly tell clients to get a legitimate appraisal of the property. That will consider things like the condition of the property in determining its fair price. When looking at the amount of equity in the property above the appropriate exemption, other issues may play into what you have to pay unsecured creditors. As an example, if you had $20,000 of nonexempt equity in the house but have $30,000 of priority taxes, then nothing would be paid to the unsecured creditors. That is because the taxman gets to stand in front of the line to get paid 1st from nonexempt assets.

The other thing I would bring to your attention is that the success rate for people who file chapter 13 cases without legal representation is basically zero.

The National Association of chapter 13 trustee's had an article a few years ago and the caption was this:
[Your Chapter 13 Case] + [No Lawyer} = [Zero Success Rate] That was NOT a joke. It is a fact. I still have a copy of the article in my office. don't even dream of trying to do a Chapter 13 reorganization without a skilled bankruptcy attorney.

This is 1 of those situations where you cannot afford to take a "Jack of all trades" attorney. Go for a specialist in the field. You can go to the State Bar website to find certified specialists in your area. You can also look at attorneys that are rated by avvo itself find one that has a 10.0 rating. Another place to look for quality bankruptcy attorneys that don't represent creditors is the National Association of
Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys website: NACBA.org.

Look for age and experience in the bankruptcy field.

Doing a Chapter 13 bankruptcy for yourself is like doing your own brain surgery. Neither will turn out well.

Good luck

Your lawyer can answer this question far better than any of us since he has facts we do not.
Your Ch13 Trustee will insist that you pay your unsecured creditors as much as they would get if you filed Ch7 and the home were liquidated. If your equity is no greater than the exemption(s) available to exempt it, then it no role whatsoever in the debt you have to pay back.
